Untitled 1.text: By asserting that Jews can be active in life and politics while simultaneously lacking the supposedly necessary unique relation to Being, Heidegger demonstrates that ontology cannot be a true transcendental condition, including of politics.

Untitled 2.text: The political space in Heidegger's texts is characterized as a threat to philosophy and to ontology, and to the unique relationship to Being which philosophy sustains.

Untitled 3.text: Heidegger suppresses or occludes the political as well as the ethical by the ontological, in contrast to other philosophers such as Immanuel Kant.

Untitled 4.text: Heidegger is reluctant to even engage with political categories and questions (e.g. economics and power).

Untitled 5.text: Individual political concepts become removed from their original context and reinterpreted to fit Heideggerian ontological framework.

Untitled 6.text: The dynamics and rhythms of the political sphere are inherently at odds with those of philosophy.

Untitled 7.text: Philosophy's fundamental task is to sustain, articulate and empower a distinctive relationship to Being.

Untitled 8.text: Politics constitutes an inauthentic mode of being.

Untitled 9.text: Heidegger argues that Jews have an inauthentic relation to being

Untitled 10.text: Jews are active in life and politics
